foods.description: Processed meat high in sodium and unhealthy fats, consumption should be limited for heart health.
Low GI fruit rich in fiber and antioxidants, supports digestion and heart health.
Low in calories and high in fiber, artichokes support liver health and digestion.
Low GI vegetable with anti-inflammatory properties, rich in folate and vitamin K.
High GI food, often refined and can cause spikes in blood sugar. Limit for better blood sugar control.
Often high in sugar and refined flour, linked to weight gain and poor blood sugar control.
Medium GI fruit, provides potassium and fiber, beneficial in moderation for energy and digestion.
Alcoholic drink that can affect blood sugar levels; moderate consumption is advised.
Low GI vegetable, rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, supports immune function.
Typically high GI, especially white bread; opt for whole grains for better blood sugar control.
Very low GI vegetable, rich in fiber, vitamins, and antioxidants, promotes heart and gut health.
Can be high in calories, sodium, and unhealthy fats depending on ingredients.
Very low GI, nutrient-dense, supports digestion and provides anti-inflammatory benefits.
Typically high in sugar and refined carbs, can cause spikes in blood sugar. Best consumed occasionally.
High in sugar, often causes quick spikes in blood sugar. Should be limited.
Medium GI fruit, provides hydration and vitamin C but should be consumed in moderation for blood sugar control.
Medium GI vegetable, good source of vitamin A, beneficial for eye health.
Medium GI fruit, high in fiber, can be beneficial for digestion but should be consumed in moderation.
Usually high in sugar and refined flour, can spike blood sugar levels. Best consumed occasionally.
Generally high in sugar and fat, can contribute to weight gain and poor blood sugar control.
High GI, fried in unhealthy oils, contributing to poor heart health and blood sugar spikes.
Medium GI fruit, high in antioxidants but should be eaten in moderation to avoid sugar spikes.
Healthy fat-rich dip made from avocados, supports heart health and is low in carbs.
Moderate GI, high in sugars and fats. Best consumed occasionally.
Usually high in refined flour and sugar, can cause spikes in blood sugar.
Low GI fruit, rich in vitamin C and fiber, supports immune and digestive health.
High GI, often made with refined flour. Can lead to blood sugar spikes.
Low GI fruit, rich in fiber, helps with digestion and blood sugar regulation.
Medium GI snack, high in fiber, but can be unhealthy if loaded with butter or salt.
High GI snack, can cause blood sugar spikes. Best consumed occasionally.
Low GI fruit, rich in antioxidants and vitamin C, supports heart health.
Low GI vegetable, rich in vitamins and antioxidants, supports heart health.
High GI, often made with refined flour, can cause blood sugar spikes.
Low in carbs but high in fat. Can be part of a healthy diet in moderation.
Alcoholic drink that may contain high sugar; moderation is important.
Low-calorie beverage that provides antioxidants, but can increase anxiety in excess.
Typically calorie-free and used to reduce cooking oil consumption.
Low-carb, high-protein seafood, provides essential minerals like zinc.
High GI pastry, rich in butter and refined flour, best eaten occasionally.
Low GI vegetable, high in water content, supports hydration and digestion.
High GI, high in sugar and fats, can cause rapid blood sugar spikes.
Low-carb, high-protein food, supports muscle repair and overall health.
Depends on the type, generally rich in vitamins and fiber, supports digestion and health.
Low GI fruit, rich in vitamin C, supports immunity and weight management.
Can be high in unhealthy fats and refined carbs, depending on ingredients.
High in sugar, should be consumed in moderation.
Processed meat high in sodium and unhealthy fats. Consumption should be limited for heart health.
General category, glycemic index varies depending on the drink. Be mindful of sugars and additives.
GI varies based on fruit content. Often high in sugar, consume in moderation to avoid blood sugar spikes.
Low GI fruit, rich in vitamin C and antioxidants, supports immune health and digestion.
Low-carb, high-protein seafood, beneficial for muscle repair and providing essential minerals.
Medium GI fruit, high in vitamins A and C. Consume in moderation to manage blood sugar levels.
Low GI beverage, provides calcium and protein. Opt for unsweetened varieties to avoid added sugars.
Very low GI, rich in nutrients and antioxidants, supports immune and heart health.
Low-carb, high in zinc and other minerals, supports immune function and overall health.
GI depends on type and preparation. Whole grain varieties have lower GI and better blood sugar control.
Often high in refined flour and sugar, leading to quick blood sugar spikes. Best consumed occasionally.
Low GI fruit, rich in vitamins A and C, beneficial for digestion and skin health.
Medium GI fruit, high in vitamins and digestive enzymes, consume in moderation to manage blood sugar levels.
GI varies based on toppings and crust. Generally high in refined carbs and fats, best enjoyed in moderation.
Medium GI fruit, rich in antioxidants and vitamins, supports heart health and has anti-inflammatory benefits.
High GI, can cause rapid spikes in blood sugar. Opt for smaller portions or alternatives like sweet potatoes.
Medium to high GI, rich in vitamins and fiber, beneficial in moderate amounts.
Low GI vegetable, low in calories, supports digestion and provides vitamin C.
GI depends on ingredients. Generally low GI if focused on vegetables; be cautious with high-fat dressings.
General category, glycemic index depends on specific food items.
GI varies depending on bread and fillings. Opt for whole-grain breads and healthy fillings.
Low-carb, high-protein seafood, supports muscle health and is low in calories.
Medium to high GI, provides vitamins and fiber, consume in moderation.
Low-carb, high-protein seafood, rich in nutrients and supports overall health.
GI depends on bread and fillings. Choose whole-grain breads and balanced fillings for better health.
GI varies with ingredients. Sushi rice is often high GI, so balance with non-starchy vegetables.
GI depends on shell and fillings. Opt for whole-grain tortillas and healthy fillings for better health.
Usually high in refined flour and sugar. Consume in moderation to avoid blood sugar spikes.
Generally low-calorie and contains antioxidants. Avoid excessive sugar or high-calorie additives.
Generally low GI, rich in vitamins and minerals. A key component of a balanced diet.
High GI fruit, provides hydration and vitamins but should be consumed in moderation.
Alcoholic beverage, impacts blood sugar differently. Moderate consumption is advised.
Medium to high GI, low in calories, provides hydration and nutrients, consume in moderation.
Very low GI vegetable, low in calories and provides vitamins and antioxidants.
GI depends on bread and fillings. Typically high in refined carbs; balance with vegetables and lean proteins.
Rice paper snack, GI not well-documented. Consumption should be balanced with other healthy foods.
Savory pancake, GI varies. Typically high in refined flour; balance with vegetables.
Noodle soup, GI depends on ingredients. Opt for healthier versions with more vegetables.
Tofu dish, GI varies with ingredients. Consume in moderation and balance with vegetables.
Broken rice dish, GI depends on preparation. Choose lean proteins and plenty of vegetables.
Fresh spring rolls, generally low GI if made with fresh ingredients and lean proteins.
Noodle soup, GI depends on broth and noodles. Opt for less fatty versions and add vegetables.
Noodle soup, GI varies with preparation. Choose lean proteins and vegetables for a healthier option.
Sticky rice dish, GI varies with ingredients. Balance with vegetables and lean proteins.
Typically made with a beef or veggie patty served in a bun. Varies in nutritional content depending on ingredients.
Indian flatbread made with white flour and butter, relatively high in glycemic index due to refined flour.
Spiced tea with milk and sugar. Popular in South Asia, but high in sugar when sweetened.
Indian whole wheat flatbread, a staple food with a moderate glycemic index, healthier than white bread.
Chickpea curry with fried bread, popular in North India. High in calories and fats.
A creamy lentil dish cooked with butter and cream. Rich in protein but also in fats.
Steamed savory cake made from fermented rice and chickpea batter. Low glycemic index and a healthy snack option.
Rice stir-fried with vegetables or meat, high in carbohydrates and often prepared with oil.
Steamed rice cake, low in fat and a low glycemic index food, common in South Indian cuisine.
Deep-fried sugary dessert, very high in glycemic index and should be consumed in moderation.
Indian street food consisting of flatbread stuffed with spicy meat or vegetables. Nutritional value depends on fillings.
Indian cottage cheese cooked in spicy gravy. A high-protein vegetarian option but can be high in fats.
Traditional Indian ice cream made from condensed milk. High in sugar and fats.
South Indian dish made of fermented rice batter and filled with spiced potato. Moderate to high glycemic index.
Steamed or fried dumplings stuffed with vegetables or meat, popular in Nepal and Tibet. Nutritional value depends on preparation.
Indian street food consisting of small, hollow puris filled with flavored water. High in carbs and sodium.
Deep-fried fritters made with vegetables and chickpea flour. High in fat and should be consumed in moderation.
Indian street food consisting of mashed vegetables served with buttered bread. High in carbohydrates and fats.
A popular fast food, typically high in refined carbs, fats, and sodium. Glycemic index depends on crust and toppings.
Deep-fried pastry stuffed with spiced potatoes or meat. High in glycemic index and fats due to frying.
